newsitem.title: MALAYSIA: Malaysia Mining explains Bakun pullout.
newsitem.headline: Malaysia Mining explains Bakun pullout.

text.p: Malaysia Mining Corp Bhd (MMC) said on Wednesday it had pulled out of the Bakun hydroelectric dam project in order to channel its resources into another infrastructure project.

"MMC feels that instead of taking up the five percent, it is best to utilise the resources for the impending implementation of (the) East Coast Highway that will need a lot of cap ital," said MMC in a statement to the Kuala Lumpur Stock Exchange.
Deputy Prime Minister Anwar Ibrahim said on Tuesday MMC's five percent stake in the dam holding company had been taken over by the government's investment arm Khazanah Holdings Bhd.
The $5.5 billion dollar Bakun dam is being developed in Sarawak state on the island of Borneo.
Anwar had told reporters on Tuesday that one reason for MMC's pullout was that it was unable to gain more say in the management of the project.
MMC was among the first companies to be involved in the dam project in 1990, the company said in its statement.

In November, the government had said that all future highway projects would be privatised. Works Minister S. Samy Vellu said that more than 100 proposals had been submitted to the government by private companies to undertake such projects.
The total cost of road works in the country to 2000 is estimated at 26 billion ringgit, said Samy Vellu.
